docs.lead_paragraph: Three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Newt Gingrich took fire for most of the evening and seemed to relish his new role as the leading Republican candidate in the field.

headline.seo: In G.O.P. Iowa Debate, Rivals Target Newt Gingrich
headline.main: Race Reshaped, Rivals Target Gingrich in G.O.P. Debate
headline.print_headline: G.O.P. Debate Sets All Eyes On Gingrich

docs.abstract: Newt Gingrich offers robust defense of his views on the Middle East, his lucrative work after leaving Congress and his conservative credentials during spirited Republican presidential debate; with weeks remaining before Iowa caucuses, Gingrich's rivals seize opportunity to raise questions about his temperament and personal life, but Gingrich appears to relish his new role as frontrunner.
docs.snippet: Three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Newt Gingrich took fire for most of the evening and seemed to relish his new role as the leading Republican candidate in the field.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is room to cut defense spending, if it is done with prudence and innovation.

headline.seo: A Pentagon the Country Can Afford
headline.main: A Pentagon the Country Can Afford
headline.print_headline: A Pentagon the Country Can Afford

docs.abstract: Editorial argues that there is plenty of room to cut defense spending without jeopardizing security, if the cuts are done with prudence and innovation; asserts that no matter what kind of compromise Congress comes up with for a deficit-reduction plan, the Pentagon needs to learn to live within the country's means.
docs.snippet: There is room to cut defense spending, if it is done with prudence and innovation.

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Reducing the perils of gargantuan institutions — and the threat to taxpayers — is an idea that seems to be taking hold in Washington.

headline.seo: A Fed Banker Wants to Break Up Some Banks

docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column holds that reducing the perils of gargantuan institutions — and the threat to taxpayers — is an idea that seems to be taking hold in Washington; cites Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas president Richard W Fisher's call for breaking up some enormous banks, and Sen Sherrod Brown's hearing on how to shield Main Street from what he calls megabank risk.
docs.snippet: Reducing the perils of gargantuan institutions — and the threat to taxpayers — is an idea that seems to be taking hold in Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: All the networks, broadcast and cable, are closely covering the Republican primary campaign, but Fox News practically owns and operates it.

headline.seo: A Republican Primary Campaign Waged on Fox News
headline.main: The Republican Primary Campaign in Iowa Is Right at Home on Fox News
headline.print_headline: The Republican Primary Campaign in Iowa Is Right at Home on Fox News

docs.abstract: Alessandra Stanley The TV Watch column observes that all television networks, broadcast and cable, may be covering the Republican primary campaign, but Fox News has devoted all of its time and shows to it; says the result is that many candidates are investing more time with the channel than on the campaign trail.
docs.snippet: All the networks, broadcast and cable, are closely covering the Republican primary campaign, but Fox News practically owns and operates it.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans included a measure supporting the Keystone XL pipeline in their bill to extend tax relief for 160 million American workers.

headline.seo: Pipeline Project Tacked Onto G.O.P. Tax Relief Bill
headline.main: House Republicans’ Bill Sets Up Pipeline Battle
headline.print_headline: House Republicans’ Bill Sets Up Pipeline Battle

docs.abstract: House Republicans, seeking to force a showdown with Pres Obama over the stalled Keystone XL oil pipeline, include a measure supporting the project in their bill to extend tax relief for 160 million American workers; say pipeline will create jobs and has support from dozens of Democrats in Congress.
docs.snippet: House Republicans included a measure supporting the Keystone XL pipeline in their bill to extend tax relief for 160 million American workers.

headline.main: Next Two Debates Likely to Be Nasty

docs.abstract: The two televised gatherings of candidates in the next week are shaping up to be the most important — and harshest — yet.
docs.snippet: The two televised gatherings of candidates in the next week are shaping up to be the most important — and harshest — yet.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a political year when debates have repeatedly reshaped the course of the Republican presidential campaign, the next two televised gatherings of candidates, on Saturday and next Thursday, are shaping up to be the most important - and nasty - yet.

docs.abstract: The United States might learn a good deal from Germany’s approach to health care insurance, which provides both a broad net and significant individual choice, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: The United States might learn a good deal from Germany’s approach to health care insurance, which provides both a broad net and significant individual choice, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: If you count spending on social services, other countries spend more to achieve a healthier society than the United States does.

headline.seo: To Fix Health Care, Help the Poor
headline.main: To Fix Health, Help the Poor
headline.print_headline: To Fix Health, Help the Poor

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Elizabeth H Bradley and Lauren Taylor, officials at Yale's Global Health Leadership Institute, argues that the United States could achieve a healthier society if it reallocated much of its health care spending toward investment in social services.
docs.snippet: If you count spending on social services, other countries spend more to achieve a healthier society than the United States does.
